summary: John Elliff is mentioned in several documents related to responses to Congressional committee requests, particularly those from the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities (SSC). The documents suggest that Elliff was likely a staff member of the Senate Select Committee, as indicated by references to security clearances for SSC staff. His involvement appears to be related to the committee's inquiries into intelligence operations, including COINTELPRO, warrantless electronic surveillances, and domestic intelligence activities. The documents span from June to September 1975, indicating a period of active engagement with the committee's work. There is no direct mention of the JFK assassination in relation to John Elliff in these documents.
key_connections: Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities
significance: Based on the provided documents, John Elliff's significance is primarily related to his role as a staff member of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities during its investigation into intelligence operations in the mid-1970s. There is no indication from these documents that he had any direct involvement or significance in the JFK assassination context.
